The original code violates the Single Responsibility Principle because the DamageCalculator class is responsible for calculating damage based on the type of character, which means it has knowledge of the internal structure of the Character subclasses. By moving the damage calculation logic into each Character subclass, we ensure that each class has a single responsibility: to represent a character and to calculate its own damage.

The original code violates the Single Responsibility Principle because the `SpeedCalculator` class is responsible for calculating the speed based on the type of vehicle, which means it has knowledge of the internal structure of `Car` and `Bicycle`. By introducing an interface `Vehicle`, we allow each vehicle type to define its own type and behavior, thus separating the responsibilities. The `SpeedCalculator` now only needs to know about the `Vehicle` interface, adhering to the principle.
